problems.yes: You have provided your DOCSTRING file, and provided instructions to run your code.
problems.no: You did not provide a DOCSTRING file and instructions to run your code.

problems.yes: You have used Overleaf and LaTeX for your report.
problems.no: You did not use Overleaf and LaTeX for your report.

problems.yes: You have provided the exact commit hash for your GitHub.
problems.no: You did not provide commit hash for your GitHub for us to consider.

problems.yes: Your report is a PDF document.
problems.no: Your report is not a PDF document.

problems.yes: Great job! Your report met the page limit requirement. Keep up the concise and focused writing.
problems.no: Your report exceeded the 8-page limit. For future reports, please aim to keep it within the required length by focusing on key points and being concise.

problems.yes: Your graphs/figures are readable. Good job!
problems.no: Your figures/graphs are not readable, it requires us to zoom while we are trying to read the graphs/figures.

problems.yes: You have used proper reference style in your report.
problems.no: You did not follow the proper reference style for your report. You could have consistently follow either APA, MLA or IEEE reference style.

problems.yes: You clearly stated an explicit hypothesis, helping to establish a focused narrative for the report.
problems.no: You needed to state an explicit hypothesis for what you expect in the report.

problems.yes: You build your hypothesis using evidence from lecture, paper, or generally known theory.
problems.no: Your hypothesis is not grounded by evidence. You should have provided explicit evidence to support the claim of your hypothesis.

problems.yes: You followed up with the hypothesis in your discussion/conclusion.
problems.no: You cannot just state a hypothesis since it needs to follow through from a narrative perspective at the end of your report.

problems.yes: You have provided direct evidence to support whether your hypothesis has been met.
problems.no: You didn't provide direct evidence to support whether your hypothesis has been met.

problems.yes: You provided full, reproducible disclosures for Randomized Hill Climbing.
problems.no: We did not find complete disclosures for Randomized Hill Climbing (restart policy, step size schedule, perturbation operator, etc.).

problems.yes: You provided full, reproducible disclosures for Simulated Annealing.
problems.no: We did not find complete disclosures for Simulated Annealing (initial temperature, cooling schedule, perturbation operator, etc.).

problems.yes: You provided full, reproducible disclosures for Genetic Algorithm.
problems.no: We did not find complete disclosures for Genetic Algorithm (population size, selection method, crossover operator, mutation rate, etc.).

problems.yes: You maintained equal function evaluation budgets across all algorithms and provided proper budget accounting.
problems.no: You did not maintain equal function evaluation budgets across algorithms or failed to provide proper budget accounting.

problems.yes: You provided progress and diagnostics with best-so-far objective curves and failure rates.
problems.no: We did not find progress curves with readable captions or failure rate reporting.

problems.yes: You used layer-aware perturbation and variation design with proper bounds and constraints.
problems.no: We did not find evidence of layer-aware proposal scales or consistent bounds across algorithms.

problems.yes: You clearly stated initialization policy and used consistent warm starts across algorithms.
problems.no: We did not find clear initialization policy or consistent warm starts across algorithms.

problems.yes: You provided results table with winner callout and mechanism-level explanation.
problems.no: We did not find comparison tables with clear winner identification and explanation.

problems.yes: You provided comparative discussion of Randomized Optimization efficacy with compute-aware analysis.
problems.no: Your report is missing focused discussion on Randomized Optimization efficacy relative to baseline methods.

problems.yes: You covered all seven required optimizers with matched budgets.
problems.no: You did not cover all seven required optimizers or failed to match budgets across methods.

problems.yes: You defined validation loss threshold and reported time/steps to reach threshold.
problems.no: We did not find validation loss threshold definition or time/steps to threshold reporting.

problems.yes: You provided sensitivity heatmaps over (α,β₁) and (α,β₂) for Adam family methods.
problems.no: We did not find sensitivity heatmaps for Adam family methods.

problems.yes: You reported validation trajectories with median and interquartile range over multiple seeds.
problems.no: We did not find stability analysis with multiple seed reporting.

problems.yes: You provided training vs. validation curves and discussed generalization gap.
problems.no: We did not find generalization gap analysis with training vs. validation curves.

problems.yes: You provided proper budget accounting with gradient evaluation counts and wall clock time.
problems.no: We did not find complete budget accounting for each run.

problems.yes: You provided comprehensive comparative discussion integrating evidence across optimizers and datasets.
problems.no: Your report is missing focused synthesis comparing speed, performance, stability, and sensitivity.

problems.yes: You maintained optimizer scope discipline using only standard Adam with best Part 2 hyperparameters.
problems.no: You performed optimizer retuning or variant substitution in Part 3.

problems.yes: You attempted all five required regularizers.
problems.no: You did not attempt all five required regularizers.

problems.yes: You compared baseline vs. best single vs. best combination regularizers.
problems.no: We did not find comparison between baseline, best single, and best combination regularizers.

problems.yes: You provided precise disclosures of regularizer values, placements, and policies.
problems.no: We did not find exact regularizer values, placements, or policy summaries.

problems.yes: You provided high-quality analysis with evidence including dispersion measures.
problems.no: Your analysis lacked evidence with dispersion measures or paired per-seed deltas.

problems.yes: You provided regularization sweep and mechanism-level explanations.
problems.no: We did not find regularization sweep comparison or mechanism-level explanations.

problems.yes: You explicitly discussed Type I and Type II errors and tied them to operating points.
problems.no: You did not discuss Type I and Type II errors or their relationship to operating points.

problems.yes: You presented at least three evidence-backed takeaways comparing algorithms and datasets.
problems.no: You presented fewer than three concrete takeaways comparing algorithms and datasets.

problems.yes: You connected results to course concepts (generalization, bias-variance, error metrics).
problems.no: You did not connect results to relevant course concepts.

problems.yes: You acknowledged limitations and named one concrete next step.
problems.no: You did not acknowledge limitations or name concrete next steps.

problems.yes: Your conclusion is consistent with reported figures/tables and cites them directly.
problems.no: Your conclusion contradicts reported results or fails to cite figures/tables.

problems.yes: You successfully implemented all three required components with proper budget limits and comprehensive analysis.
problems.no: Not applicable
